captions.text:
One of the biggest secrets of physics is that
we still don't fundamentally understand what

happens when the smallest things interact
with big things - that is, when quantum mechanics

meets our everyday world.
You've probably heard of the "Schrodinger's

Cat" experiment where a particle (in this
case a cat) is in a superposition of two states

(both dead and alive) at once, until it interacts
with the outside world - normally a photon

of light that we send in to see what's going
on (but it could also just be a random particle

that has nothing to do with us). Upon interaction
with the outside world, the cat is observed

as being either dead, or alive, but not both.
The problem is, physics can't explain how

the cat, or particle, goes from being in a
combination of two states at once to being

in "just one", or "just the other"; nor do
we know how the "decision" is made.

This isn't just a problem with cats, either
- it plagues every single quantum mechanics

experiment, famous or otherwise, from the
double slit experiment and quantum teleportation

to the Stern-Gerlach experiment and tests
of the Bell inequalities. In every case, we

can predict how likely it is for a particle
to be in one state or another, but have no

clue how it actually ends up that way.
That's where the many-worlds picture of quantum

mechanics comes in - basically, "many-worlds"
proposes the idea that the quantum system

doesn't actually decide - rather, at every
junction where large everyday stuff interacts

with a quantum system, the timeline of history
splits and both possibilities happen on different,

alternate branches. You know, a choose-your-own-adventure
where every possible story happens. In this

scenario, we'd think that only one possibility
happened because we'd be stuck on one of the

branches, in a version of ourselves that only
sees one possibility happen. In some ways,

this sounds pretty fishy - I mean, it's hard
to test the reality of a universe that hides

its true nature from us by not allowing us
to test or observe its true nature.

But anyway, in the many-worlds picture of
quantum mechanics, "branch-points" are predicted

to happen all the time, everywhere. Pretty
much any time subatomic particles interact

with each other, or with anything else, anywhere
in the universe, there are multiple possible

outcomes. Which means a LOT of branching of
history. There may even be infinitely many
branches.

So is the Many Worlds hypothesis true? We
don't know - it hasn't yet been tested experimentally.

There's a bit of mathematics that supports
it, and there are also a number of mathematical

models that don't require such an extravagantly
big & complex picture of the universe. But

luckily, physics is science, not speculation,
and eventually, someone, maybe even you, will
perform an experiment that helps us
discover the truth.

comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
+Vercingetorix 39 *Are you asking what rules govern which universe "you" 
observe?*
Yes, that's exactly what I meant!

*What is really "you?"*
Whatever my consciousness observe is the reality that I exist in.

*Perhaps there are none*
But in that case this theory didn't prove why anything happens.

*There is no way to access or interact with them, and while they may be 
there, they are not in any of our spatial dimensions.*
In that case it is also impossible to prove ... and still doesn't explain 
why anything happens in the way it does.

*Exploring the idea of other universes is something that, for now, is out 
of our reach.*
Absolutely.

Good answer, but it just showed that we know nothing about this so far... 
One day perhaps! Until then, researching and speculating is what we can do.
comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
+The Lappin Are you asking what rules govern which universe "you" observe? 
If it is, the satisfying answer you want merges quantum physics with 
philosophy. What is really "you?" There could be infinite universes in 
which a human with almost the exact same characteristics as you exist, but 
these are an infinitely small percent of all the possible universes if 
every particle interaction causes another split. Most of the universe 
splits have absolutely nothing to do with "you." Anyways, back to the 
rules. Perhaps there are none. I mean, (with what we know now, at least) 
for all intents and purposes, those other universes do not exist. There is 
no way to access or interact with them, and while they may be there, they 
are not in any of our spatial dimensions. Every thought "you" have is a 
result of a series of subatomic particle interactions, so do we have any 
identity at all? Well, if the other universes are not in our spatial 
dimensions, the universe you see is the only one that exists to the 
inhabitants of our universe. Our universe is unfathomably big, and there 
are trillions of questions we don't know the answers to. Exploring the idea 
of other universes is something that, for now, is out of our reach.
comments.author: Vercingetorix 39

comments.text:
+Gaerteuth I never asked "why" as in "to what purpose". I was asking about 
"why" as in "what rules resulted in that outcome". Your question was a 
correct answer, but I was searching for a satisfying answer to the question 
on a quantum level, since no rules has been found there to describe the 
outcome as of today.
comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
+The Lappin Well, that's a different question entirely, but I have no 
problem answering it. The laws of physics are descriptions of the 
Universe's behavior. Their first and foremost function is to set up a 
framework that relates different behaviors of the universe to each other by 
using mathematical relationships. Force = Mass times Acceleration only 
shows that given these definitions, axioms, and laws, these 3 ideas relate 
to eachother in this way. It's not a property of the Universe, per se, but 
a property of how we understand it.

We get the outcome we get because that's how it works. There's nothing 
special about that. The universe as far as we can tell, will always behave 
in a consistent, repeatable way. As such, the descriptions we create (the 
laws of physics) are also consistent by definition, which is why math is 
the language of choice for it.

I think what you're really asking is, "Why does the universe behave the way 
it does?" Nobody knows, and nobody needs to know either, because the answer 
to that question is inconsequential to anything bound by the Universe. 
Whether we know why the universe behaves in one way and not the other way 
does not change the fact that it WILL behave that way. There's not really 
any opportunity as far as I can tell for us to change the behavior of the 
Universe- I fear that if we did, we might make it unstable and/or 
unsuitable for us to live in.
comments.author: Project

comments.text:
+Gaerteuth
Let's frame the question like this:
" *How* does the laws of physics work and *why* do we get the outcome that 
we get? "
comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
+The Lappin You don't see how vapid it is to ask "Why is something the way 
it is instead of some other way"? There's no way to answer it. It's like 
asking why the laws of physics are the way they are. The only answers 
people give to that question are fallacies of irrelevant thesis, and 
begging the question. 

Not only is it impossible to answer your question without a fallacy, but 
the answer to that question if there is one is completely inconsequential 
to the asker- the reason for this is that it you are trapped in your 
branch, and cannot make contact with other branches. They are of no 
consequence to you.
comments.author: Project

comments.text:
+Gaerteuth Science is all about asking questions such as "Why?" How would 
we learn if we don't ask?
comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
+The Lappin Since when does it need to explain why you are in a particular 
branch? That's as meaningless of a question as "Why do I live in 2015 
instead of 1944?"
comments.author: Project

comments.text:
+Vercingetorix 39 The infinite/multi universe theories are indeed 
interesting and it wouldn't surprise me if they turned out to be true, but 
as I said in my original comment, it doesn't explain why this particular 
branch is the one that I experience.

On the matter of freedom; does bigger impact equal more freedom? I would 
say that that depends. If you think that your decisions are what determine 
what branch you experience, then yes. But that would mean that your will 
would be some type of unearthly force that can choose how the laws of 
physics work. That idea would require a lot of explanation in itself, 
wouldn't it? That would mean that your will would either be a random toss 
of a coin, (that would not be a very free will,) or some complicated system 
that isn't determined by your brain only (since your brain isn't known to 
decide what the laws of physics let you do).

In either case I think the freest will is when I decide things by 
processing information and than making the decision based on logical 
non-random conclusions that are well thought through. Then I know that it 
is my will that dictates my actions. But that's just my opinion, and as far 
as I know, things aren't always true just because I would prefer if they 
were.
comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
+The Lappin If universe branching is based on particle interaction, there 
would potentially be a new universe created every second, right? So there 
could be a universe where nothing changed for humanity, but an electron in 
some Hydrogen atom moved in a slightly different direction than another 
universe. Millions of these universes could be almost the same as the one 
our consciousness is in. So every second, the branch that *my* 
consciousness (I'll call it consciousness because that's the only thing I 
can comprehend) is in is expanding through infinite new universes, created 
by any new possibility for any tiny particle! Because particles make up 
everything and are constantly moving, human actions, though they may have 
larger effects, would influence a low percentage of the universes. This 
means that cognitive choices are on almost a different level than universe 
branching, right? But thoughts are electric signals in your brain, which of 
course is made of particles...so any particle interaction anywhere could 
trigger a chain reaction, causing a blossom of new universes, some of which 
would cause you to do something, releasing another new wave of universes, 
some of which would...I think the only thing I succeeded in here is 
confusing myself. The point is, using our sense of "self" and imagining 
that thoughts are the products of our environments and quantum objects 
within them could mean that we have infinite freedom, and parallel 
universes are simply a result of our decisions. But the more you think 
about it, we are a very small part in a very large universe that is 
constantly expanding through infinite branches of more universes.
comments.author: Vercingetorix 39

comments.text:
+Gaerteuth But on a cognitive level... It is still *your* will. It is still 
*your* choices. The difference is that it is a non-random process. But how 
does that mean it's not free? What do you want it to be free from? Reason? 
Reality?

There's no right or wrong answer here. It all depends on your perception, 
but it's interesting to think about.

comments.author: The Lappin

comments.text:
Quite easy. We call it cause and effect.

If I cause a ball to drop to the ground, I can only observe branches where 
the effect is a ball dropping to the ground. Mainly because of the laws of 
physics severely limiting the possible branches. For instance, the laws of 
physics are already set. We cannot ever experience a branch where the laws 
of physics are different from how they already are. So in effect, I'll 
never get to see a "branch" where a ball falls up, not down. No free will, 
no woo, just cause and effect. Effects follow causes. Laws restrict effects.

comments.author: Logan Jennings

comments.text:
It can't be whether or not a sentient being observes the phenomena that 
decides the outcome. That doesn't make sense what so ever!

Anyway, this is what Wikipedia says:

*Objective collapse theories*
According to objective collapse theories, superpositions are destroyed 
spontaneously (irrespective of external observation) when some objective 
physical threshold (of time, mass, temperature, irreversibility, etc.) is 
reached. Thus, the cat would be expected to have settled into a definite 
state long before the box is opened. This could loosely be phrased as "the 
cat observes itself", or "the environment observes the cat".
Objective collapse theories require a modification of standard quantum 
mechanics to allow superpositions to be destroyed by the process of time 
evolution. This process, known as "decoherence", is among the fastest 
processes currently known to physics.


Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schr%C3%B6dinger%27s_cat

comments.text:
It's not that complicated actually. The particle is in a superposition of 
decayed and not decayed, the cat is in a superposition of dead and alive, 
and you are in a superposition of observing a dead cat and an alive cat. 
All the outcomes happen but you only observe one branch of events.
comments.author: John Becker

comments.text:
There HAS to be multiple universes for the same reason that just about 
everything else we see is not unique in the universe. If one universe 
exists, then we know that universes are possible. If universes are 
possible, and it has happened once, then we know that it can happen again. 
And this is where it gets crazy: it must have happened an infinite number 
of times and continue to be happening because there is a good chance that 
whatever exists outside of this universe is timeless and has always 
existed, will always exist, and is not bound by any of the rules that bind 
things within our universe. Causality and temporality are aspects of our 
world, but it seems to be a necessary conclusion that they don't exist 
outside of it, because if they did then the existence of any universe would 
be impossible (because it would need a primal cause, a thing which creates 
a logical contradiction with causality).

I hope that made sense.﻿
comments.author: Joseph Flammens

comments.author: PaladinswordSaurfang

comments.text:
2:05 *...that don't require such an extravagantly big and complex picture 
of the universe*

Misleading straw-man nonsense. The many-worlds interpretation is NOT 
complex. It is incredibly simple. It is the most simple interpretation of 
quantum mechanics that exists, because it avoids all of the problems of the 
wave-function collapse. The fact that it involves an infinite number of 
universes is not an indication of complexity. Complexity comes about by the 
number of ad hoc hypotheses and assumptions needed, and the MWI relies on 
very few assumptions. So the many-worlds interpretation is the most 
reasonable interpretation.

Maybe stick to educating people instead of subtly adding in your own 
uninformed opinions.﻿
comments.author: PaladinswordSaurfang

comments.author: meghan486

comments.text:
I have many reasons to be sure that this theory is true. One of them is 
that if the many worlds theory isn't true, it means choice is indeed an 
illusion. And I'm fairly sure I take conscious choices one way or another.

Why do I say that? Well, the theory of relativity proved that time is a 
fixed dimension. Time isn't a story being written every fraction of a 
second... both the past and future are already there. If we could see in 4 
dimensions instead of 3, we'd see an extrusion of ourselves as a baby in 
one side, and one of ourselves as an old man / lady in the opposite. So 
time cannot be modified, simply experienced as is.

This leaves only one solution to the issue of free will: Every possibility 
must already exist. From the smallest one to the largest... even us 
thinking or not thinking a given thought at a certain moment. Consciousness 
somehow has the ability to jump to different timeline branches based on a 
pattern... *but* can only stick to one at a time.﻿
comments.author: MirceaKitsune

comments.text:

bound by cause and effect, every action is a reaction. Maybe you 'chose' to

circumstances allowing you to be on youtube 'caused' you to watch it, and 
then the way you took the video according to your perceptions 'caused' you 
to comment. You couldn't have not commented because you did. I think it may 
be more probability than choice. Whatever upringing the uploader had, his

It's easy to at least see how this works in practice actually. Look for 
images / videos of > 3D objects... such as hypercubes. Time is the 4th 
dimension... and if multiple outcomes exist, it means multiple times can be 
stocked in the above dimension (the 5th). As living beings, we experience 
the first 3 dimensions as space, the 4th as time / motion, and the 5th we 
couldn't notice at all... except when seeing quantum leaps perhaps.

comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 You can't argue against thousands of quantum experiments, 
equations, and accurate predictions with "common sense." What is 
interesting about quantum mechanics is that classical intuitions that you 
are saying have to be true are simply not true at scales we cannot directly 
observe. Quit trying to use your opinions based on personal observations 
against science.
comments.author: John Becker

comments.text:
It is not factually determined before then. Quantum objects really do exist 
in two states at one time before they become entangled with the outside 
environment. It's been proven countless times in experiment and that's one 
of the first things you learn in quantum mechanics. Quantum objects ARE in 
two places or two different states AT THE SAME TIME. They've gotten objects 
to do this at larger and larger sizes. 
https://www.ted.com/talks/aaron_o_connell_making_sense_of_a_visible_quantum_object
comments.author: John Becker

comments.text:
+jakemichie97
Maybe we should *treat* things as if us observing something causes a 
decision to be made, but shouldn't we also *realize* that factually, it is 
determined before then?

Common sense dictates that a tree falling in a forest without observers 
still makes a sound. We all know that to be true. We also know that the 
exact sound it made is set in stone, we just don't *know* which sound it 
made.

Our discovering which sound it made, is not going to determine which sound 
it made. That's exactly like quantum mechanics, in that we cannot prove 
what kind of sound the tree made when falling without observers present, 
but we can only make assumptions.

It is foolish to say that it's *LITERALLY* a matter of chance, and the only 
thing that causes it to be a matter of chance is the fact that nobody 
observed it, though. Making such claims is a crime against obvious common 
sense.

Something doesn't get determined unless observed? No, it *does!* We just 
don't *know* it! We can use randomness to make assumptions, it actually is 
useful for that purpose, but we shouldn't start saying it's *literally* 
chance! That's impossible!
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 Are you asking what makes this current instance of your 
consciousness in this "branch", choose which branch you "go down" next?

There's no real way to answer that without leaving questions unanswered. In 
quantum mechanics, a binary decision that is unobserved is technically both 
option A and option B at the same time, until you observe it.

When talking about the "branches" relative to your consciousness, then it's 
your choices that determine what "path" you travel. Say you have 3 
different shirts in your drawer, red, orange and blue. Until you choose 
which one you wear, all 3 are being worn in the 3 possible futures, all at 
the same time. It's when you open your drawer and choose which one to wear 
that determines which path /this instance/ of your consciousness chooses.

Relative to basically any observable event in the universe, it's all down 
to probability if no conscious observer is present to observe the event, 
and control the event. In my previous example, you had the choice of which 
path you wanted to take. A photon of light emitted from the sun has two 
possibilities, A. it somehow reaches your eye (the exact process it took to 
reach your eye is not important), or B. it did not reach your eye. Now, 
remove all control you have over the experiment, say your head is clamped 
down in such a way that you cannot move it /at all/. Your eye's are forced 
to look dead straight, you cannot move them either. So there is no possible 
way you can manipulate the experiment for the outcome to be what you want 
it to be. If we simply ignored every single object in the path of that 
photon, and treated the experiment as it either reaches your eye or it 
doesn't, there's an even 50 / 50 chance for that photon to reach your eye. 
You cannot control it, so you cannot make this photon reach your eye or not 
if you wanted to. It's down to probability as to what the outcome is.

This is all just my opinion and belief on it, the whole topic of parallel 
universes is honestly opinionated for the time being until factual evidence 
is present. You may not believe it to work the way I described, but I do.
comments.author: jakemichie97

comments.text: +What's His Name Again? now we are just going pre sup for no reason lol.
comments.author: eddieisfiction

comments.text:
+eddieisfiction I second +What's His Name Again?'s comment. He took the 
words right out of my mouth.


Also, you basically just said 'this universe can never be deterministic 
because its impossible in this universe'. Can't argue with that, it makes 
sense and it's *totally* not circular at all... -__-
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+eddieisfiction No. Even though I don't think that everything is 
deterministic, it's not a stupid assumption to make. You label things as 
facts where no one has a definite answer. "Because it's impossible in this 
universe" <-- what do you know? You *believe* it is impossible? Ok, no 
problem. But you put it as a fact and try to convince someone else is 
*wrong*? That, on the other hand, is a problem.
There is no wrong or right in this issue. Honestly, why can't people just 
have a *discussion* where they exchange their point of views (PoV)? All I 
see are (partially aggressive) debates where one absolutely has to convince 
the other that their PoV is the right one...
comments.author: What's Their Name Again?

comments.text:
+Therm6000 Therm stop going christian on me.  Nothing is 100% predictable. 
 That's a stupid assumption to make ok?  No one in science will ever claim 
to have a 100% predictability of anything.  Because it's impossible in this 
universe.  That's why this universe can never be deterministic at all.
comments.author: eddieisfiction

comments.text:
+eddieisfiction
Read the whole thing below, please. It explains what just happened.

I'm not claiming that my definition is the correct one, nor am I relying on 
philosophy right now. I'm not 'making terms my own definitions'. It is 
simply a fact that there are multiple correct interpretations of the word 
'predictability', so we are *both* right, and yet we had a misunderstanding 
because of it.

In my last comment to you, I explained the misunderstanding we had based on 
our different personal definitions of the word predictability, and why I 
misunderstood your meaning.

When *I* say predictable, I mean deterministic, I mean predictable with 
100% certainty. You must be able to predict what *WILL* happen. It's not a 
wrong definition, and I didn't make it up.

And when I hear the word from other people, without any further explanation 
/ context, I will think they mean *predictable with certainty* too, unless 
they specifically explain otherwise. I have to choose one or the other, 
after all. That mindset made your claim seem like a blatant contradiction 
to me.

The misunderstanding we had stems from the fact that *your* definition of 
the word predictability is that you're able to make assumptions or guesses 
about the future. You must be able to predict what *MIGHT* happen. With 
*your* definition of 'predictability', your claim is not contradictory: in 
that case, you *can*, in fact, predict randomness; just *without* certainty.

As you can clearly see, the issue we had was completely unrelated to 
philosophy, or me not 'going with what works in reality'. I wasn't making 
up definitions or philosophies, because we *both* had potentially correct 
definitions of the word 'predictability'.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 You need to stop making terms your own definitions and you need 
to stop relying on philosophy to explain science.  When someone says 
something is predictable... it doesn't mean they are saying it's not 
random, and it doesn't mean they are saying it's deterministic.  You need 
to learn this now.  Drop the philosophy, and go with what works in reality.
comments.author: eddieisfiction

comments.text:
+What's His Name Again?
I think there's a finite amount of knowledge to be had in this world. If 
everything is determined, there has to be a catch-all set foundation/rule. 
(or multiple) Heck, the same goes for if everything is random, in which 
case the foundation is, well, just random!

But either way, I think we will end up knowing everything, all we need is 
enough time. If the foundation exists, it can also be found after a 
(un-)certain amount of time, whether it's deterministic or random. If the 
foundation doesn't exist, then how does the universe?
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 I respect you for that.
I, on the other hand, believe that there is no fundamental sense and that 
it is just randomness. However, it could be true that, as science will 
further develop, we will get a better understanding how everything is 
interconnected and eventually randomness will vanish.

But I hope not. It is somewhat romantic that not everything can be 
predicted; it leaves a certain charm to the universe (yeah, a very 
subjective and not very scientific reason, huh?).

Now you argue of course that everything is determined, regardless of humans 
understanding it or not - which can make sense, I guess, but so does 
assuming the opposite. :)

The thing is, I think that the more we discover, the more there is to 
discover. Metaphorically, if science opens one door, there are numerous new 
closed doors behind. I don't think we will ever run out of things we don't 
understand and that is why, regardless if everything is determined or not, 
I believe that randomness will always be around in our human universe :)
comments.author: What's Their Name Again?

comments.text:
+What's His Name Again?  Okay, that much is fair. What I *AM* going to 
phrase as a fact though, is that we can't draw a 100% conclusion about this 
theory yet, and it seems there are some people here who phrase their 
opinions on the matter as fact too. That frustrates me, and now I'm doing 
the same thing... :\

I stated at the start that it was my opinion, but then I went overboard 
with it. I am convinced that it will turn out that randomness is an 
illusion though, and I won't be convined otherwise unless it's irrefutably 
proven. If a way is found that randomness starts making actual sense, I'll 
bite. We'll just have to wait and see.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 I respect your opinion, but you cannot simply state "[b]ut by 
nature everything is deterministic. There is no such thing as chaos" as a 
fact. These are your convictions and I am positive you have thoroughly 
thought them through. But just because it is true to you, that doesn't mean 
you should phrase as if it were globally accepted.
comments.author: What's Their Name Again?

comments.text:
+eddieisfiction
It seems that the only difference now is our own personal *definitions* of 
the *word* predictablity.

In my mind, 'predictable' means you can be 100% certain about an exact 
outcome. This does not occur in randomness by definition. To me, 
predictable means predictable *with certainty*. You must KNOW something to 
predict that it WILL happen.

In your mind, however, 'predictable' doesn't nessecarily mean you have to 
be 100% certain. You just have to able to make a rough approximation of 
what *might* happen. To you, predictable means *being able to make 
approximations/guesses*.

I am of the opinion that approximations are only required if you don't have 
all of the knowledge. If you can't be certain, you're missing a variable. 
Therefore, in this situation I can only draw the conclusion that people are 
missing some information, for they have drawn an impossible conclusion that 
makes no sense *by definition*.

*Accepting* that life just doesn't make sense means that we're *accepting* 
the fact that we don't know the variables. That is fine in principle, heck, 
perhaps it IS impossible to ever get all variables, but don't call it 
*actual* randomness! It isn't *actually* randomness, we just don't/cannot 
know the truth. But by nature everything is deterministic. There is no such 
thing as chaos, so we don't have to find order in it either.

We should *treat* it like randomness while making assumptions/guesses, but 
*realize* that it isn't really actual randomness.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 Therm there's a problem with your argument that predictability 
has to equal determinism.  Determinism requires destiny, predictability 
doesn't.  You can have things that are from randomness that are 
predictable.  It's completely allowed.  Maybe not in philosophy, but it is 
in science, you know, the real world?  So you need to re-examine what you 
are doing there if you don't understand reality.
comments.author: eddieisfiction

comments.text:
+eddieisfiction Randomness isn't predictable at all. All patterns and 
so-called predictability are just complete randomness. You can't predict it 
with certainty, thus it isn't predictable. Predictable = deterministic. You 
can't predict something that can't be predicted by it's very *nature*. You 
can only make guesses and assumptions, which is completely different.

You're saying that finding order in chaos wasn't meant to be, I agree. But 
I'm saying: what if we all just THINK it's chaos, but in reality it was 
order all along? What if it turns out that it's impossible for chaos to 
exist in the first place, because it doesn't make any sense by *nature*? 
Because of what it *IS*?

+What's His Name Again?
I'm asking because consciousness is the *missing link*. You cannot find the 
truth about this issue without accepting it as truth. Leaving it out will 
result in unanswered questions.

People are saying that their theories are already airtight, but I'm 
presenting a factual hole in their theories by asking this question.

It's an important point, and yet, it always seems like it can be left out 
of scientific issues without any problems. But then you won't be able to 
find the whole truth.

And its existence is clear yet unprovable. Its meaning cannot even be 
*conveyed* to anybody else without room for misinterpretation. It's 
frustrating, but it's impossible for it to be an illusion. If that's what 
people think, that means they don't know what I'm speaking of.
comments.author: Therm6000

comments.text:
+Therm6000 No, because there is also predictability to be found with 
patterns in the randomness.  But it isn't determinism. You can find order 
in chaos.... But it doesn't mean it's meant to be.  You are going to black 
and white.  It's too religious for my taste.
comments.author: eddieisfiction

comments.text:
nothing to do with consciousness - any instrumentation you set up to make 
an equivalent 'observation', like a camera, or particle detector, or 
photocell, depending on what's being observed, would also only record one 
outcome. And in the other worlds, the other similar instruments would also 
record the 'other' single outcomes.
comments.author: Dick Hamilton

comments.text:

You are asking a question that has no answer (yet). Why insist on it so

preferred over another.
I think I know what you intend to ask and I agree that everyone fails to 
answer your question, but that is because no one is and will be able to 
give you an answer as for now.

comments.text:

This theory would allow time travel without paradoxes. I won't explain how, 
but it seems like it could work.
However, there are two problems with many worlds time travel. One, If you 
sent someone else through time, then had them come back, I don't think it 
would be gauranteed that you would see them again. Also, it would seem like 
there would constantly be infinite time travelers all over the place. I'm 
not an expert on infinity or time travel, but...I just wanted to say that.﻿

comments.text:
Here's the thing about this theory it's more complex than the video 
describes,it depends on what occurs sometimes the timeline narrows back to 
one possibility,for example a student is late by 5 mins in his last 
class,in one timeline he gets punished the other he gets left off with a 
warning however at the same time he leaves school in the exact same 
way,it's why we can't understand it because things get shared into the same 
timeline at some point it's why we know things without even knowing how we 
obtained that knowledge...I mean it's happened to me before I remember 
knowing stuff where I have no idea of learning it in this time line,so 
there's a 50/50 chance this theory actually is true﻿
